test.question: According to the information given in the map, which of the following conclusions can be drawn?
answers: The British colonies were the main destination of African slaves.
South America did not allow the importation of slaves.
Most slaves were sent to work on sugar plantations in Brazil and in the Caribbean.
South America has a large population of African origin today.
The main slave-trading region in Africa stretched 550 miles long.
test.answer: Most slaves were sent to work on sugar plantations in Brazil and in the Caribbean.

test.question:
The Earth is divided into 24 time zones. The Earth rotates 15 degrees in one hour, so each time zone equals 15 degrees of latitude. The map illustrates the four time zones across the continental United States. 

According to the map, what time is it in Dallas when it is noon in Sacramento?

The Earth is divided into 24 time zones. The Earth rotates 15 degrees in one hour, so each time zone equals 15 degrees of latitude. The map illustrates the four time zones across the continental United States. 

What time is it in Sacramento, CA, when it is midnight in Tampa, FL?

The Earth is divided into 24 time zones. The Earth rotates 15 degrees in one hour, so each time zone equals 15 degrees of latitude. The map illustrates the four time zones across the continental United States. 

As a traveler moves west, she can expect to
answers: change time zones.
move into an earlier time zone for every 15 degrees of latitude she travels.
experience jet lag.
move into an earlier time zone for every 15 degrees of longitude she travels.
move into a later time zone for every 15 degrees of latitude she travels.
test.answer: move into an earlier time zone for every 15 degrees of latitude she travels.

test.question:
The Earth is divided into 24 time zones. The Earth rotates 15 degrees in one hour, so each time zone equals 15 degrees of latitude. The map illustrates the four time zones across the continental United States. 

In past presidential elections, television networks have made predictions about which candidate is likely to win before the polls closed throughout all of the nation's time zones. 

Which of the following statements explains why this would anger some voters?
answers: The polls close later in New York than in Chicago.
Voters in the Central time zone want to know who won in the eastern states.
Polls in the Pacific time zone open earlier if voters want their votes to be counted.
Polls close one hour later in the Mountain time zone than in the Central time zone.

Predictions based on voting in eastern time zones influence those who have not yet voted in 
the more western time zones.
test.answer:
Predictions based on voting in eastern time zones influence those who have not yet voted in 
the more western time zones.

test.question: The greatest increase in population growth rate between 1950 and 2000 occurred in

The world population growth rate dropped one percentage point between the mid-1950s and 1960. 

Which of the following best explains this occurrence?
answers: There were more births and fewer deaths in the mid-1950s than there were in 1960.
A baby boom in the decade after World War II caused a spike in the birth rate.
The introduction of the birth control pill in 1960 in the United States helped slow the birth rate.
There were more births in 1960 than there were in the mid-1950s.
There were more deaths in 1960 than there were in the mid-1950s.
test.answer: There were more births and fewer deaths in the mid-1950s than there were in 1960.

test.question: Which of the following statements is proved by the information in the two graphs?
answers: The population will reach its limit by 2050.
When the rate of population growth decreases, so does the population.
When the rate of population growth increases, so does the population.
The rate of population growth will reach an all-time low in 2050.
Even though the rate of population growth is decreasing, the population is increasing.
test.answer: Even though the rate of population growth is decreasing, the population is increasing.

test.question: Which of the following natural resources is least likely to be affected by acid rain?
answers: animal life
plant life
coal reserves
water
forest
test.answer: coal reserves

test.question: Which of the following is NOT a cause of acid rain?
answers: human activity
natural phenomena
volcanoes
lakes and streams
traffic
test.answer: lakes and streams

test.question: Which of the following is NOT a purpose of this form?
answers: Notifying the government that you have changed your name.
Registering with a political party.
Applying for U.S. citizenship.
Registering to vote in an upcoming local election.
Indicating that you have moved and will be voting in another district.
test.answer: Applying for U.S. citizenship.

test.question: Which of the following expresses a fact rather than an opinion?
answers: States have different requirements about who is eligible to vote.
The voting age should be changed from 18 to 21 years of age.

Every state should institute a 'voter-motor' program in which people can register
 to vote at the same time that they are registering their motor vehicle.
The government should allow noncitizens to vote.
Voting should be considered a privilege, not a right.
test.answer: States have different requirements about who is eligible to vote.

test.question:
The electoral college is a group of electors who choose the president and vice president. Each state is allowed the same number of electors as its total number of U.S. senators and representatives-so each state has at least three electors. 

In most states, the candidate who wins the most popular votes earns that state's electoral votes. 

Based on the information in the map, which of the following might be true of Kerry's campaign strategy?
answers: It focused on winning the states in the southeast.
Kerry targeted his campaign efforts in his home state of Massachusetts.
It targeted states that have large populations and a large number of electoral votes.
It focused on winning most of the states with small populations.
Kerry campaigned vigorously in George W. Bush's home state of Texas.
test.answer: It targeted states that have large populations and a large number of electoral votes.

test.question: Which of the following is NOT a true statement?
answers: George W. Bush won a larger number of states.
Kerry was popular in New England.
If Kerry had won Florida's electoral votes, he would have become president.
If Kerry had won New Hampshire's electoral votes, he would have become president.
Bush did not appeal to most voters on the west coast.
test.answer: George W. Bush won a larger number of states.

test.question: Which of the following conclusions can you make from the information in the map?
answers: Women are more likely than men to vote for the Democratic Party.
Increasing numbers of Americans consider themselves political independents.

The Sunbelt-the southern and southwestern states-was once a stronghold of the
 Democratic Party.
There were distinct regional differences in voting patterns.
You can not make any predictions about voting patterns based on region.
test.answer: There were distinct regional differences in voting patterns.

test.question: Which of the following is NOT a purpose of education as expressed in the quotation?
answers: To expose children to values.
To explain the government's education budget.
To prepare those who might serve the country as soldiers.
To produce good citizens.
To give kids a chance to succeed at life.
test.answer: To explain the government's education budget.

test.question: According to the passage, how might the court define 'equal educational opportunity'?
answers: Schools with the same quality of teaching.
Schools with the same quality of facilities and materials.
Schools that only admit students based on sex.
Schools that separate minority students to give them a better chance.
Schools of the same quality and welcome all students regardless of race.
test.answer: Schools of the same quality and welcome all students regardless of race.

test.question: Which of the following situations is NOT protected by the First Amendment?
answers: A New York Times editorial criticizes the government's foreign policy.
A neo-Nazi group applies for a permit and stages a rally in a public square.
A police officer reads a suspect his rights.
A group meets in a chapel to worship.
Students protest federal budget cuts in education.
test.answer: A police officer reads a suspect his rights.

test.question: Which of the following instances is NOT protected by the Sixth Amendment?
answers: A person accused of a crime silently prays before his trial begins.
A person accused of drug trafficking hires a lawyer to defend him.

A trial is moved to another area because no jurors could be found who had not heard 
of the crime and had an opinion about who committed it.
A lawyer informs an accused person of her charges.
A lawyer cross-examines witnesses who testify against her client.
test.answer: A person accused of a crime silently prays before his trial begins.

test.question: Based on the information in the graph, which of the following proposals might best improve the voting rate?
answers: Distribute umbrellas to all households to encourage people to vote on rainy election days.
Organize buses to help people get to voting places.
Send reminders to registered voters so they do not forget to vote.
Reschedule Election Day to a weekend so that people who are busy at work and at school can be available to vote.
Provide more interesting candidates that inspire people to vote.
test.answer: Reschedule Election Day to a weekend so that people who are busy at work and at school can be available to vote.

test.question: According to the graph, how many eligible U.S. citizens are NOT registered to vote?
answers: 19 million
56 million
76 million
92 million
130 million
test.answer: 56 million

test.question: Which of the following statements can you infer from the passage?
answers: Congress is more powerful than the president.

Congress tries to get the president to accept its provisions by attaching provisions to a bill 
that the president supports.
A president is more effective when members of the same political party are the majority in Congress.
If a president vetoes a bill, there is no way to get it passed into law.
Bills that the president vetoes are unconstitutional.
test.answer:
Congress tries to get the president to accept its provisions by attaching provisions to a bill 
that the president supports.

test.question: Which of the following conclusions can you make based on the passage?
answers: It is easier to rewrite and make a bill more acceptable to the president than it is to override a veto.

It is easier to override a veto than it is to rewrite and make a bill more acceptable 
to the president.
The U.S. Constitution gives the president the power to edit the bills he receives from Congress.

The system of checks and balances ensures that president has no influence over the 
lawmaking branch of government.
Presidents rarely use their power to veto.
test.answer: It is easier to rewrite and make a bill more acceptable to the president than it is to override a veto.

test.question: Which of the following party systems would Emerson most likely support?
answers: One in which with citizens are loyal to a political party at all costs.
A two-party system.
A system with a liberal party that advocates for change and a conservative party that maintains tradition.
One in which citizens are independent and think for themselves.
A multi-party system.
test.answer: One in which citizens are independent and think for themselves.

test.question: Which of the following party systems would Mill most likely support?
answers: One in which with citizens are loyal to a political party at all costs.
A two-party system.
A system with a liberal party that advocates for change and a conservative party that maintains tradition.
One in which citizens are independent and think for themselves.
A multi-party system.
test.answer: A system with a liberal party that advocates for change and a conservative party that maintains tradition.

test.question: Which of the following statements is an implication of judicial review?
answers: The Constitution is a historic document with little influence over how the government operates today.
The Constitution must explicitly state which branch of government is to have what authority.
The framers never meant for the Supreme Court to have this power.
If Supreme Court justices were elected, the power of judicial review would be justified.
The Constitution is a living document that continues to be interpreted.
test.answer: The Constitution is a living document that continues to be interpreted.

test.question: Which of the following best describes the purpose of judicial review?
answers: To declare a law unconstitutional.
To follow public opinion polls.
To determine the country's changing needs.
To propose new laws.
To adapt the Constitution to what the court feels is right.
test.answer: To declare a law unconstitutional.

test.question: Joe McNeil has not directly stated, but would support, which of the following statements?
answers: Without the sit-in in Greensboro, NC, the civil rights movement would never have started.
Woolworth's served affordable lunches.
Local NAACP chapters were causing trouble and upsetting citizens.
Nobody was surprised when black college students took a seat at the all-white lunch counter.
The college students showed courage when they participated in the Greensboro sit-in.
test.answer: The college students showed courage when they participated in the Greensboro sit-in.

test.question: What is the author's purpose in including Joe McNeil's quotation?
answers: To show that young people are the most likely to push for societal change.
To demonstrate that everyone has a different point of view.
To give a firsthand account of what has become a historic event.
To discount the importance of the civil rights movement.
To show that the college students had not intended to create a stir.
test.answer: To give a firsthand account of what has become a historic event.

test.question: Who are the women in this photograph addressing?
answers: Other women who say they don't want the right to vote.
President Woodrow Wilson
Abolitionists
Suffragettes
Isolationists
test.answer: President Woodrow Wilson

test.question: With which of the following statements would the photographer most likely agree?
answers: Women should behave in a dignified and orderly manner even if they are protesting.
Women stand outside the gates of governmental power.
The suffragettes would be more effective if they had more powerful slogans.
Demonstrations are the most effective ways to influence lawmaking.
Demonstrations are always ineffective.
test.answer: Women stand outside the gates of governmental power.

test.question: What does the author of this passage believe?
answers: The U.S. government was faithful to its treaties with Native Americans.
Native Americans made up a homogenous group.
The European settlers were responsible for the decimation of Native people.
Native cultures were unsophisticated.
The Europeans benefited from contact with Native cultures.
test.answer: The European settlers were responsible for the decimation of Native people.

test.question: Which of the following messages did Paul Revere most likely want to convey in his engraving?
answers: American colonists should not protest the presence of British troops in Boston.
The British troops were defending themselves against rowdy gangs of colonists.
British troops savagely killed unarmed citizens.
Americans should willingly pay British taxes on imports of glass, paper, paint, and tea.
British troops used only necessary force in dealing with the rioting crowd.
test.answer: British troops savagely killed unarmed citizens.

test.question: What can you infer was Revere's purpose in creating and selling the engraving?
answers: Make a large profit for himself.
Calm the rebellious spirit of Boston citizens.
Create support for the British empire.
Represent both sides of the event.
Fuel the revolutionary cause.
test.answer: Fuel the revolutionary cause.

test.question: What is the purpose of the paragraph?
answers: To praise the advances of printing technology.
To connect the early advances in printing with today's technological advances.
To show that technological advances can develop in different geographical areas over periods of time.
To give credit to Gutenberg for the first movable-type printing press.
To show how Gutenberg's invention made printed materials more widely available.
test.answer: To show that technological advances can develop in different geographical areas over periods of time.
